column1: What do Fault Domains (FD) primarily protect against?
column4: Rack, power, or network hardware failures
column7: Fault Domains protect against simultaneous hardware failures by distributing VMs across separate physical racks with independent power and network. A hardware failure in one rack only affects VMs in that specific fault domain.

column1: What do Update Domains (UD) protect against?
column4: Planned maintenance that may reboot VMs
column7: Update Domains ensure application availability during planned maintenance by isolating VMs into groups that reboot sequentially. Only one UD is updated at a time, keeping VMs in other UDs running.

column1: How many Fault Domains are supported in most Azure regions?
column4: Up to 50 FDs in large regions
column7: Most Azure regions support 2-3 fault domains for hardware isolation, with newer regions typically supporting 3 FDs. The exact number varies by region based on datacenter infrastructure configuration.

column1: How many Update Domains can an Availability Set support?
column7: Availability Sets support up to 20 update domains with a default configuration of 5. This configurable limit allows fine-grained control over maintenance sequencing for high-availability applications.

column1: Which domain determines how Azure spreads VMs across physical racks?
column7: Fault Domains control VM distribution across physical hardware infrastructure including separate racks, power supplies, and network switches. Azure automatically spreads VMs across available FDs to maximize hardware isolation.

column1: Which domain determines how Azure sequences VM reboots during maintenance?
column7: Update Domains control the sequencing of VM reboots during planned Azure maintenance operations. Azure updates one UD at a time, ensuring predictable and controlled maintenance windows.

column1: In an Availability Set, Azure distributes VMs across what combinations?
column7: Availability Sets distribute VMs across both Fault Domains and Update Domains simultaneously for comprehensive protection. FDs provide hardware isolation while UDs ensure maintenance availability.

column1: Which VMSS orchestration mode supports up to 1000 Fault Domains?
column7: VMSS Flexible orchestration mode supports up to 1000 fault domains for maximum spreading capability across physical infrastructure. This provides significantly greater fault isolation than Uniform mode's 5 FD limit.

column1: Which VMSS orchestration mode supports only up to 5 Fault Domains?
column7: VMSS Uniform orchestration mode is limited to 5 fault domains with platform-managed spreading. This mode prioritizes identical VM instances over maximum fault domain distribution.

column1: What is the default number of Update Domains in an Availability Set?
column7: The default Availability Set configuration includes 5 update domains for balanced maintenance sequencing. This can be customized up to a maximum of 20 UDs based on application requirements.

column1: What do Fault Domains represent inside Azure?
column2: Network ACLs used for VM protection
column4: Physical groupings of racks, power, and network
column7: Fault Domains are physical groupings representing VMs that share common rack infrastructure, power source, and network switch. VMs in the same FD are vulnerable to the same hardware failure events.

column1: When Azure performs planned maintenance, which domain ensures only some VMs reboot?
column7: Update Domains ensure only a subset of VMs reboot during planned maintenance by grouping VMs into sequential update batches. Azure processes one UD at a time, maintaining service availability throughout maintenance.

column1: What is the key difference between Fault Domains and Update Domains?
column2: FDs control maintenance; UDs control hardware
column3: FDs are software-only; UDs are hardware-only
column4: FDs protect against hardware failure; UDs protect against maintenance events
column7: Fault Domains protect against physical hardware failures (rack, power, network) while Update Domains protect against planned maintenance disruptions. Together they provide comprehensive availability coverage for different failure scenarios.

column1: Which scenario requires Fault Domains more than Update Domains?
column7: Surviving rack or power failures requires Fault Domain protection since FDs isolate VMs across separate physical infrastructure. Update Domains cannot protect against hardware failures, only maintenance events.

column1: Which scenario requires Update Domains more than Fault Domains?
column4: Mitigating planned updates and maintenance restarts
column7: Mitigating planned maintenance requires Update Domain protection since UDs control sequential reboot scheduling during updates. Fault Domains cannot help during maintenance events that require coordinated VM reboots.

column1: If a region only supports 2 Fault Domains, how many can you configure?
column4: You cannot increase it beyond the region limit
column7: Fault Domain limits are determined by physical datacenter infrastructure and cannot be increased beyond regional maximums. Some older regions support 2 FDs while newer regions support 3 FDs.

column1: Azure spreads VMs across Fault Domains and Update Domains when you use what feature?
column7: Availability Sets automatically distribute VMs across both Fault Domains and Update Domains for comprehensive protection. Azure handles the distribution without manual configuration required.

column1: What ensures a portion of your application stays online during sequential updates?
column7: Update Domains ensure application availability during sequential maintenance by keeping VMs in non-updated UDs running. Only one UD updates at a time, maintaining service continuity throughout maintenance windows.

column1: Which domain is associated with hardware-level isolation?
column7: Fault Domains provide hardware-level isolation by distributing VMs across separate physical racks with independent power and network. This physical separation protects against correlated hardware failures.

column1: Which domain is associated with maintenance-level sequencing?
column7: Update Domains control maintenance-level sequencing by grouping VMs into batches that update sequentially. Azure processes UDs one at a time with completion waiting between batches.
